content.description: Starts off a boulder into a dirty crack system for 10-15 feet, and then busts left through a beautiful, slanting, offset fingercrack. If only it were longer...15m
content.protection: small cams to a #2,  stoppersRap Anchor to descend.
content.location: To the right of Mirage Crack, on the east face of Freshman Mtn.

content.description: Despite the name, this climb is a lot of fun and on solid rock. Climb up a jumble of boulders to reach several crack systems in a dihedral. Climb this for 30 feet and the cracks fade down to a single narrowing crack and the angle of rock lessens. The next 10 feet the crack is clogged with dirt and leaves, but the climbing is fairly easy. The climb is easy to protect, but setting an anchor can be tricky.
content.location: Far right side of Mirage Wall, just to the right of Wimpy Crack. There are no anchors at the top, so the descent requires a climb down the back, but its fairly easy. Walk off to the right.

content.description: starts with thin hands and ends with fist jams

This is a slightly overhanging crack that narrows and widens between finger and hand jams. There is a fixed BD Red #1 (old school) cam just above your first solid hand jam. I worked on it for a while and it isn't going anywhere so if everything stays the same, feel free to clip it. Crack finishes much wider, so don't be afraid to use the horizontal crack towards the top.
content.location: Right of lvy league, left of Mirage

content.description: A quality crack for sunny days as it's shaded by the trees. The crux is the OW top half. This pumpy route is definitely worth the effort to find.
content.protection: Trad rack - med. to large pieces for OW. Rap Anchor to descend
content.location: Follow the loop trail NE along Sandy Creek to the crossing which heads between Buzzards Roost and Freshman Mt. Go NW and look for a cliff band hidden in the trees. Mirage crack is the tallest route on Mirage Wall, right of a large leaning tree.

content.description: Enter a description of this area.
